column3: An acute bacterial infection of the lining of the intestines by Shigella sonnei (aka group D Shigella), Shigella flexneri (aka group B Shigella) or Shigella dysenteriae type 1, a deadly variant prevalent in developing countries
Other bacterial infections not related to bacterial foodborne intoxications, tuberculosis enteritis or detailed in above codes.

Persistent diarrhea lasting 2 weeks or more secondary to infection by E. coli strains.  It spreads to humans through contact with contaminated water and/or infected animals, typically in developing countries.

An invasion of the intestinal wall by the protozoan parasite Entemoeba histolytica.  The disease is prevalent throughout the developing nations of the tropics, at times reaching a prevalence of 50% of the general population and is estimated to cause more than 100,000 deaths per year.

A symptomatic form of amoebiasis (E. histolytica infection) characterized by abdominal cramping, diarrhea, fatigue, excessive flatus, tenesmus, unintentional weight loss and, in more severe forms, bloody stools, abdominal tenderness, fever and vomiting.
A symptomatic form of amoebiasis (E. histolytica infection) characterized by long-standing infection and severe diarrhea.
Small bowel inflammation secondary to rotavirus infection resulting in abdominal pain, cramping, diarrhea, fever and dehydration

Caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis, repiratory TB spreads from person to person through the air and produces a cough with sputum, dyspnea and chest pain as well as evening fever, night sweats, weight loss, appetite loss, fatigue and muscle weakness
A specific presentation of respiratory TB, localized to the upper respiratory tract (i.e. larynx, trachea and bronchii)

A disease characterized by the establishment of scattered Mycobacterium tuberculous foci (tubercles) in the brain, meninges or adjacent bone during the bacillemia that follows primary infection or late reactivation TB elsewhere in the body.
(see code A18) A common form of extrapulmonary tuberculosis commonly involving cervical nodes.
A disease characterized by systemic muscle spasms arising in newborns who are delivered in unsanitary conditions and subsequently infected with Clostridium tetani.
aka "lockjaw," a disease characterized by systemic muscle spasms arising from Clostridium tetani infection after contamination of an open wound by soil, saliva or feces
(see code A36) diphtheria infection localized to the larynx
A sexually transmitted Treponema pallidum infection characterized in the early stages by lymphadenopathy and the formation of a painless chancre at the point of entry.
(see code A51) primary syphilis of an area not detailed in codes (A51.0-A51.1)

An early manifestation of tertiary syphilis characterized by chronic, insidious meningeal inflammation and subsequent cognitive and/or behavioral impairment, ataxia, stroke, ophthalmic symptoms, urinary symptoms, lightning pains, headache, dizziness, hearing loss and/or seizures.
Tertiary syphilis not detailed in codes A52.0-A52.3 (i.e. late benign [gummatous])

A sexually transmitted Trichomonas vaginalis infection, usually causing symptoms in women including green or yellow discharge from the vagina, itching in or near the vagina and discomfort with urination.

Typically, a herpex simplex type 2 (HSV2) - but can be an HSV1 - viral infection characterized clinically by the eruption of painful, grouped vesicular lesions on a erythematous base that can recur months to years after primary inoculation

Acute hepatitis A is a liver infection caused by the hepatitis A virus (HAV). The virus is spread when an uninfected (or unvaccinated) person eats or drinks something contaminated by the stool of an HAV-infected person: this is called faecal-oral transmission. The disease is closely associated with inadequate sanitation and poor personal hygiene. Unlike hepatitis B and C, hepatitis A infection does not cause chronic liver disease and is rarely fatal, but it can cause debilitating symptoms.

An acute illness caused by infection by the hepatitis B virus with symptoms that last several weeks, including yellowing of the skin and eyes (jaundice), dark urine, extreme fatigue, nausea, vomiting and abdominal pain. Recovery can take several months to a year.
Chronic hepatic inflammation secondary to hepatotropic (hepatitis A-E), adenovirus, cytomegalovirus, Epstein-Barr or herpes simplex viral infection

Acute, inflammatory, contagious disease caused by Rubulavirus and characterized by swelling of the salivary glands, especially the parotids, and sometimes of the pancreas, ovaries, or testes; spread by direct contact, airborne droplet nuclei, fomites contaminated by infectious saliva, and perhaps urine (with other complications)

Infection by nematodes of the genus ASCARIS. Ingestion of infective eggs causes diarrhea and pneumonitis. Its distribution is more prevalent in areas of poor sanitation and where human feces are used for fertilizer.  *Intestinal complications may include (radiating) abdominal pain, distention, colic, nausea, anorexia or intestinal obstruction.

A primary or metastic neoplasm involving the base of the tongue, often  associated with chronic alcohol and tobacco use, older age, certain geographic locations, a family history of upper aeordigestive tract cancers and/or certain nutritional deficiencies and infectious agents.
A primary or metastic neoplasm involving the sublingual gland, one of 3 major pairs of salivary glands in humans, which accounts for less than 5-10% of all salivary gland tumors
Congenital bulging or out-pouching of the small intestine secondary to the in-utero partial obliteration of the vitelline duct

A primary or metastatic malignant tumor involving a digestive organ or organs not detailed in codes C15-C25 (including intestinal tract [part unspecified], spleen, overlapping lesions of the digestive tract and other ill-defined sites within the digestive system)
A series of diseases including Waldenstrom macroglobulinaemia, immunoproliferative small intestinal disease and MALT-lymphoma each characterized by malignant proliferation of lymphoid cells
Malignant oesophageal carcinoma which has not (yet) invaded adjacent tissues (Stage 0 [N0, M0])
Malignant stomach carcinoma which has not (yet) invaded adjacent tissues (Stage 0 [N0, M0])
A malignant epithelial neoplasm which is confined to the epithelial layer without evidence of further tissue invasion

A neoplasm of the oropharynx which is characterized by the absence of morphologic features associated with malignancy (severe cytologic atypia, tumor cell necrosis, and high mitotic rate). Benign neoplasms remain confined to the original site of growth and only rarely metastasize to other anatomic sites.

A neoplasm of the nasopharynx which is characterized by the absence of morphologic features associated with malignancy (severe cytologic atypia, tumor cell necrosis, and high mitotic rate). Benign neoplasms remain confined to the original site of growth and only rarely metastasize to other anatomic sites.

A neoplasm of the colon, rectum, anus and/or anal canal which is characterized by the absence of morphologic features associated with malignancy (severe cytologic atypia, tumor cell necrosis, and high mitotic rate). Benign neoplasms remain confined to the original site of growth and only rarely metastasize to other anatomic sites.

A neoplasm of other and/or ill-defined parts of the digestive system which is characterized by the absence of morphologic features associated with malignancy (severe cytologic atypia, tumor cell necrosis, and high mitotic rate). Benign neoplasms remain confined to the original site of growth and only rarely metastasize to other anatomic sites.
This term refers to other nonmalignant tumors of skin that are not classified under a different code
Benign smooth muscle neoplasms arising from the body of the uterus that project into the endometrial cavity
Other non-malignant tumors of the uterus not detailed in codes D25.0-D25.9

A neoplasm of the ovary which is characterized by the absence of morphologic features associated with malignancy (severe cytologic atypia, tumor cell necrosis, and high mitotic rate). Benign neoplasms remain confined to the original site of growth and only rarely metastasize to other anatomic sites.

A neoplasm of the penis which is characterized by the absence of morphologic features associated with malignancy (severe cytologic atypia, tumor cell necrosis, and high mitotic rate). Benign neoplasms remain confined to the original site of growth and only rarely metastasize to other anatomic sites.

Anemia characterized by decreased or absent iron stores, low serum iron concentration, low transferrin saturation, and low hemoglobin concentration or hematocrit value. The erythrocytes are hypochromic and microcytic and the iron binding capacity is increased.
A decrease in red blood cell mass secondary to nutritional deficiency not detailed in codes D50-D53
A decrease in red blood cell mass due to premature destruction of erythrocytes in the spleen or peripheral vessels secondary to G6PD or other enzyme deficiency
A condition characterized by the near absence of red blood cell precursors in bone marrow, often associated with thymomas and autoimmune disorders
A decrease in red blood cell mass secondary to haemorrhage, often secondary to trauma

Disorders characterized by spontaneous or near spontaneous bleeding caused by a defect in clotting mechanisms (BLOOD COAGULATION DISORDERS) or another abnormality causing a structural flaw in the blood vessels (HEMOSTATIC DISORDERS).
A condition characterized by a reduction in the normal function of the spleen
A form of exaggerated spleen function characterized by splenic enlargement secondary to splenic vein thrombosis and/or portal hypertension
Conditions characterized by a deviation from or interruption of the normal structure or function of the spleen not detailed in codes D73.0-D73.5
Conditions characterized by a deviation from or interruption of the normal structure or function of the blood and blood forming tissues not detailed in codes D70-D77
A disorder characterized by an inability to mount a normal immune response due to antibody (i.e. immunoglobulin) defects
A disorder characterized by inadequate neonatal thyroid hormone production secondary to iodine deficiency
Enlargement of the thyroid gland due to follicular multiplication, unaccompanied by hyperthyroidism or thyrotoxicosis
A hypermetabolic condition associated with elevated levels of free thyroxine and/or free triiodothyronine resulting in excess synthesis and secretion of thyroid hormone
Coma secondary to low blood sugar concentration and/or tissue utilization (defined as < 50 mg/dL)

Aka hyperpituitarism, a disease characterized by hypersecretion of ADENOHYPOPHYSEAL HORMONES such as GROWTH HORMONE, PROLACTIN, THYROTROPIN, LUTEINIZING HORMONE, FOLLICLE STIMULATING HORMONE and/or ADRENOCORTICOTROPIC HORMONE
Pituitary dysregulation/disorders secondary to hypothalamic dysfunction not detailed in codes E23.0-E23.2
Disorders of the reproductive system resulting from pathologic androgen production secondary to abnormalities in cortisol and/or aldosterone production
Other androgenic disorders of the reproductive system not detailed in code E25.0
Other/unspecified adrenal diseases characterized by the progressive destruction of the adrenal cortex not detailed in codes E27.0-E27.3
Idiopathic overstimulation of the adrenal medulla resulting in pathologic epinephrine/norepinephrine-mediated sympathetic output
Pathological processes of the OVARY
aka Premature Ovarian Syndrome (POF)/ovarian insufficiency, a disorder characterized by a failure of the ovary to function adequately in women younger than 40 years old
Pathological processes of the TESTIS.

In pre-puberty, a disorder characterized by atrophied testes and sterility, abnormal height and absence of secondary sex characteristics.  In post-puberty, a disorder characterized by depressed sexual function, loss of sex drive and sterility, muscle weakness and osteoporosis (due to loss of the androgen anabolic effect).
1 of 3 forms of serious protein-energy malnutrition (vs kwashiorkor E40, marasmic kwashiorkor E42), caused primarily by a deficiency in calories and energy in children from developing countries
Nutritional (short stature, stunting) and/or physical retardation due to inadequate protein and/or essential nutrient intake
Disorders caused by deficiencies in B vitamins other than Thiamine and Niacin (including B2, B6, B9 and B12)

A childhood disorder characterized by decreased mineralization of bone at the growth plate secondary to vitamin D deficiency, vitamin D metabolism error and/or abnormal inorganic phosphate excretion resulting in growth retardation and delayed skeletal development
Bowed legs and/or arms, knock-knees, deformities of the thoracic cage and/or spine and/or skeletal dysplasia secondary to chronic or advanced rickets

Excessively high accumulation of body fat or adipose tissue in relation to lean body mass; the amount of body fat (or adiposity) includes concern for both the distribution of fat throughout the body and the size of the adipose tissue deposits; individuals are usually at high clinical risk because of excess amount of body fat (BMI greater than 30)
Abnormal or excessive fat accumulation secondary to excess caloric intake
Abnormal or excessive fat accumulation not detailed in codes E66.0-E66.2
A series of conditions characterized by dysfunctional lipoprotein metabolism and/or metabolite absorption and transport
A condition in which there is a deviation or interruption in the processing of a specific mineral in the body: its absorption, transport, storage, and utilization
Any disorder resulting in pathologic plasma fluid volume, osmolarity, acid-base or salt imbalance
Serum sodium concentrations in excess of 145 mmol/L; increased serum concentration of osmotically active particles
Serum sodium concentrations of less than 135 mEq/L; decreased serum concentration of osmotically active particles

Unspecified psychological or behavioral abnormalities associated with a dysfunction of the brain; history and physical examination or laboratory tests demonstrate the presence of a specific organic factor judged to be etiologically related to the abnormal mental state and loss of previously acquired functional abilities
Other disorders defined as schizophrenia not detailed in codes F20.0-F20.7

aka "satyriasis" (M), "nymphomania" (F), a disorder characterized by a desire to engage in sexual activities at a level considered abnormally high in relation to normal development and/or which causes distress or serious problems for the person affected
One of several ways in which an individual is unable to participate in a sexual relationship as he or she would wish due to psychosomatic mechanisms not detailed in codes F52.0-F52.7

Bacterial infections of the leptomeninges and subarachnoid space [NEC], frequently involving the cerebral cortex, cranial nerves, cerebral blood vessels, spinal cord and nerve roots; causative organism varies with age and clinical status (eg, postoperative, immunodeficient, posttraumatic states); clinical manifestations include the acute onset of fever, stiff neck, altered mentation, seizures, and focal neurologic deficits; death may occur within 24 hours of disease onset; pathologic features include a purulent exudate in the subarachnoid space, and diffuse inflammation of neural and vascular structures.

Other disorders secondary to chronic bacterial meningitis, encephalitis intracranial and/or intraspinal abscess and/or granuloma and/or intracranial and/or intraspinal phlebitis and/or thrombophlebitis
A group of genetic disorders characterized by slowly progressive incoordination of gait and often associated with poor coordination of hands, speech, and eye movements
A group of autosomal-recessive disorders characterized by progressive weakness of the lower motor neurons
Other syndromes characterized by head and/or face pain not detailed in codes G43.0-G43.9 (i.e. cluster headache, vascular headache, tension-type headache, drug-induced headache, etc)

Brief reversible episodes of focal, nonconvulsive ischemic dysfunction of the brain having a duration of less than 24 hours, and usually less than one hour, caused by transient thrombotic or embolic blood vessel occlusion or stenosis. Events may be classified by arterial distribution, temporal pattern, or etiology (e.g., embolic vs. thrombotic). (From Adams et al., Principles of Neurology, 6th ed, pp814-6)

Damage to a single nerve or nerve group of the upper limb (not including central nervous structures such as the brain, brainstem or spinal cord), resulting in a loss of movement, sensation and/or autonomic function)

Damage to a single nerve or nerve group of the lower limb (not including central nervous structures such as the brain, brainstem or spinal cord), resulting in a loss of movement, sensation and/or autonomic function)

Disease or damage involving the SCIATIC NERVE, which divides into the PERONEAL NERVE and TIBIAL NERVE (see also PERONEAL NEUROPATHIES and TIBIAL NEUROPATHY). Clinical manifestations may include SCIATICA or pain localized to the hip, PARESIS or PARALYSIS of posterior thigh muscles and muscles innervated by the peroneal and tibial nerves, and sensory loss involving the lateral and posterior thigh, posterior and lateral leg, and sole of the foot. The sciatic nerve may be affected by trauma; ISCHEMIA; COLLAGEN DISEASES; and other conditions. (From Adams et al., Principles of Neurology, 6th ed, p1363)
Disease or damage to the medial and/or lateral plantar nerves, branches of the tibial nerve below the level of the tarsal tunnel secondary to insult other than tarsal tunnel syndrome (G57.5)
Peripheral neuropathy of the intercostal nerves
Idiopathic muscular disorders

A heterogeneous group of nonprogressive motor disorders caused by chronic brain injuries that originate in the prenatal period, perinatal period, or first few years of life. The four major subtypes are spastic, athetoid, ataxic, and mixed cerebral palsy, with spastic forms being the most common. The motor disorder may range from difficulties with fine motor control to severe spasticity (see MUSCLE SPASTICITY) in all limbs. Spastic diplegia (Little disease) is the most common subtype, and is characterized by spasticity that is more prominent in the legs than in the arms. Pathologically, this condition may be associated with LEUKOMALACIA, PERIVENTRICULAR.
A collection of syndromes affecting parasympathetic and/or sympathetic neurons, often in conjunction with other somatic neuropathies

A syndrome complex composed of three conditions which represent clinical variants of the same disease process: STRIATONIGRAL DEGENERATION; SHY-DRAGER SYNDROME; and the sporadic form of OLIVOPONTOCEREBELLAR ATROPHIES. Clinical features include autonomic, cerebellar, and basal ganglia dysfunction. Pathologic examination reveals atrophy of the basal ganglia, cerebellum, pons, and medulla, with prominent loss of autonomic neurons in the brain stem and spinal cord. (From Adams et al., Principles of Neurology, 6th ed, p1076; Baillieres Clin Neurol 1997 Apr;6(1):187-204; Med Clin North Am 1999 Mar;83(2):381-92)

Other conditions in which there are deviations from or interruption of the normal structure(s) or function of the parasympathetic or sympathetic divisions of the autonomic nervous system not detailed in codes G90.0-G90.4
Conditions in which there are deviations from or interruption of the normal structure(s) or function of the parasympathetic or sympathetic divisions of the autonomic nervous system [NOS]
(NEC) This term refers to disorders of nervous system that are not elsewhere classified.
Non-infectious skin diseases affecting the eyelid
Inflammation of the lacrimal gland or lacrimal sac.
Rapid onset inflammation of the tissues surrounding the orbit
Abnormal protrusion of both eyes; may be caused by endocrine gland malfunction, malignancy, injury, or paralysis of the extrinsic muscles of the eye.

Rapid or abrupt onset of inflammation of the mucous membrane that covers the posterior surface of the eyelids and the anterior pericorneal surface of the eyeball.  It is often characterized by subconjunctival hemorrhage, sudden swelling of the eyelids and congestion, redness, and pain in the eye.
Persistent or recurrent onset of inflammation of the mucous membrane that covers the posterior surface of the eyelids and the anterior pericorneal surface of the eyeball.

Inflammation of the mucous membrane that covers the posterior surface of the eyelids and the anterior pericorneal surface of the eyeball, often causing swelling, itching, burning, discharge and redness. Causes might include bacterial or viral infection, allergies, irritating substances in the eye, contact lens products, or eye drops or ointments.
Benign cysts which often appear as small, clear, fluid-filled inclusions of conjunctival epithelium whose goblet cells secrete into the cyst and not onto the surface.
Inflammation of the white, opaque, fibrous, outer tunic of the eyeball.

Rapid or recent onset of inflammation of the iris and ciliary body characterized by exudates into the anterior chamber, discoloration of the iris, and constricted, sluggish pupil. Symptoms include radiating pain, photophobia, lacrimation, and interference with vision.

A clouding of the lens of the eye, which impedes the passage of light. Most cataracts are related to ageing, although occasionally children may be born with the condition, or cataract may develop after an injury, inflammation or disease.

Disease of the nervous tissue membrane of the eye (retina) as a complication of diabetes. It is characterized by the progressive microvascular complications, such as aneurysm, interretinal edema, and intraocular pathologic neovascularization.
Any condition of the transparent, semigelatinous substance that fills the cavity behind the crystalline lens of the eye and in front of the retina.
Suppurative inflammation of the tissues of the internal structures of the eye; often caused by fungi, necrosis of intraocular tumors, or retained intraocular foreign bodies.

Misalignment of the visual axes of the eyes due to the inability of the ocular muscles to move the eye resulting from neurologic deficit or muscular dysfunction. This may be caused by tumor, infection, or injury to the brain or the eye.
Also known as strabismus.  Misalignment of the visual axes of the eyes due to other or unspecified cause.
An accumulated mass of the yellow or brown waxy secretions produced by apocrine glands in the external ear canal that adheres to the wall of the external auditory canal.
Rapid onset inflammation of the mastoid bone, located in the skull just behind the ear. It is often a complication of otitis media.
Persistent or recurrent inflammation of the mastoid bone, located in the skull just behind the ear. It is often a complication of otitis media.
A temporary or persistent opening in the central portion of the tympanic membrane. Clinical signs depend on the size, location, and associated pathological condition.

Rapid onset inflammation of the tympanic membrane, often causing painful blisters on the tympanum. It may occur with a middle ear infection (otitis mediaotitis media), and it is generally a viral or bacterial infection. Rarely, it may be caused by an infection with mycoplasma pneumoniamycoplasma pneumonia.

Persistent or recurrent inflammation of the tympanic membrane, often causing painful blisters on the tympanum. It may occur with a middle ear infection (otitis mediaotitis media), and it is generally a viral or bacterial infection. Rarely, it may be caused by an infection with mycoplasma pneumoniamycoplasma pneumonia.
Labyrinthitis is an ear disorder that involves irritation and swelling of the inner ear.
Pain in one or both ears
unable to define

A nonspecific symptom of hearing disorder characterized by the sensation of buzzing, ringing, clicking, pulsations, and other noises in the ear in the absence of appropriate corresponding external stimuli.

Rheumatic fever is an inflammatory disease that begins with a strep throat caused by Group A Streptococcusbacteria. It can affect many of the body's connective tissues Â— especially those of the heart, joints, brain or skin. Rheumatic heart disease is a condition in which the heart valves are damaged by rheumatic fever.

Heart failure is a condition in which the heart can't pump enough blood throughout the body. Heart failure does not mean that your heart has stopped or is about to stop working. It means that your heart is not able to pump blood the way it should

Hemorrhoids are swollen, inflamed veins around the anus or lower rectum. They are either inside the anus or under the skin around the anus. They often result from straining to have a bowel movement. Other factors include pregnancy, aging and chronic constipation or diarrhea.
Rapid onset inflammation of the pharynx, (back of the throat, between the tonsils and the voicebox (larynx)).
Rapid onset inflammation of the pharynx, (back of the throat, between the tonsils and the voicebox (larynx)) due to a specifically identified organism not classified elsewhere.
Rapid onset inflammation of the pharynx, (back of the throat, between the tonsils and the voicebox (larynx)) with unspecified etiology.

Rapid onset inflammation of the large airways in the lung, including any part of the bronchi.  It is often viral in origin, e.g.myxovirus (i.e. influenza A,B,C, parainfluenza, HRS virus), adenovirus, and picoma viruses (e.g. rhinoviruses).
Rapid onset inflammation of the large airways in the lung, including any part of the bronchi, due to infection with the haemophilus influenzae virus.

Vasomotor rhinitis is a form of non-allergic inflammation of the nasal mucosa that is characterized by nasal congestion and posterior pharyngeal drainage. Allergic rhinitis is inflammation of the nasal mucosa that is triggered by certain allergens, such as pollen, animal fur, etc.
Persistent or recurrent inflammation of the nasal mucosa in one or more of the paranasal sinuses.

Any persistent or recurrent disease affecting the round-to-oval mass of lymphoid tissue embedded in the lateral wall of the pharynx (tonsils) or the collection of lymphoid nodules on the posterior wall and roof of the nasopharynx (adenoids)
Persistent or recurrent inflammation of the round-to-oval masses of lymphoid tissue embedded in the lateral wall of the pharynx (tonsils)
Unusual enlargement of one or more of the round-to-oval masses of lymphoid tissue embedded in the lateral wall of the pharynx (tonsils).  It can be due to infection

Persistent or recurrent inflammation of the larynx (airway) and/or the larynx and the cartilaginous and membranous tube descending from the larynx and branching into the right and left main bronchi (trachea).
Persistent or recurrent inflammation of the larynx (airway)
Persistent or recurrent inflammation of the  larynx (major airway) and the trachea (cartilaginous and membranous tube descending from the larynx and branching into the right and left main bronchi).
Loss of function or feeling of one or both of the vocal folds, often caused by injury or disease to the nerves of the larynx.
Any other disease which affects the larynx and which is not coded elsewhere.
Any other disease which affects the Larynx (the funnel-shaped fibromuscular tube that conducts food to the esophagus, and air to the larynx) and which is not coded elsewhere.

A chronic disease of the bronchial, the air passages leading to and from the lungs characterized by recurrent attacks of breathlessness and wheezing, which vary in severity and frequency from person to person.
Status asthmaticus is a sudden intense and continuous aggravation of a state of asthma, marked by dyspnea to the point of exhaustion and collapse and not responding to the usual therapeutic efforts.
A diffuse parenchymal lung disease, often caused by inhalation of dust and by tissue reaction to their presence.
Pulmonary edema is a condition caused by excess fluid in the lungs. This fluid collects in the numerous air sacs in the lungs, making it difficult to breathe.
Suppurative inflammation of the pleural space.
Presence of fluid in the pleural cavity resulting from excessive transudation or exudation from the pleural surfaces.
Any other condition effecting the thin serous membrane enveloping the lungs and lining the thoracic cavity

Gingivitis is inflammation of the gum tissues (gingiva) without loss of connective tissue.#Periodontal disease can refer to any pathological process involving the the gum (GINGIVA), the alveolar bone (alveolar process), the dental cementum, and / or the periodontal ligament
Inflammation of the soft tissues of the mouth, such as mucosa; palate; gingiva; and / or lip, as well as any associated any pathological or traumatic discontinuity of tissue
Other types of inflammation of the soft tissues of the mouth, such as mucosa; palate; gingiva; and / or lip.
Any other condition affecting the lip and/or oral mucosa
Any condition effecting the lips
Plicated tongue, also called lingua dissects, fissured tongue, or scrotal tongue, represents a change in the dorsal surface of the anterior two thirds of the tongue.
Inflammation of the esophagus, the tube that leads from the back of the mouth to the stomach.

Achalasia is a disorder of the tube that carries food from the mouth to the stomach (esophagus) due to a failure of the lower esophageal sphincter to relax, which affects the ability of the esophagus to move food toward the stomach
An opening or hole in the esophagus, the tube through which food passes from the mouth to the stomach.
Gastritis refers to inflammation of the mucosa lining of the stomach.  #Duodenitis refers to inflammation of the duodenal mucosa.
Rapid onset inflammation of the mucosal lining of the stomach with associated belleding or abnormal blood flow.
Rapid onset inflammation of the mucosal lining of the stomach due to cause not otherwise coded
Inflammation of the gastric mucosa due to alcohol use
Persistent or recurrent inflammation of the lamina propria, limited to the outer third of the mucosa in the foveolar area.

Persistent or recurrent inflammation of the gastric mucosa with atrophy leading to decreased hydrochloric acid concentration in the gastric juice. Atrophic gastritis frequently progresses from chronic gastritis.
Persistent or recurrent inflammation of the lamina propria, limited to the outer third of the mucosa in the foveolar area of unspecified origin.
Acute inflammation of the vermiform appendix.
A hernia occurs when part of an internal organ bulges through a weak area of muscle. Most hernias occur in the abdomen. Inguinal hernia is the most common type and is in the groin.
A hernia occurs when part of an internal organ bulges through a weak area of muscle. Most hernias occur in the abdomen. Umbilical, as one type of hernia, is around the belly button.

A hernia caused by weakness of the anterior ABDOMINAL WALL due to midline defects, previous incisions, or increased intra-abdominal pressure WITH concomitant death and putrefaction of tissue usually due to a loss of blood supply
A chronic inflammatory bowel disease affecting the small intestine
A chronic inflammatory bowel disease affecting the large intestine
Intestinal ischemia characterized by blood supply to the gastrointestinal tract that is inadequate to meet its metabolic demand
Long standing intestinal ischemia characterized by blood supply to the gastrointestinal tract that is inadequate to meet its metabolic demand
Other causes of intestinal ischemia characterized by blood supply to the gastrointestinal tract that is inadequate to meet its metabolic demand
A series of disorders resulting in decreased or aborted intestinal motility without intestinal hernia
A type of ILEUS, a functional not mechanical obstruction of the INTESTINES. This syndrome is caused by a large number of disorders involving the smooth muscles (MUSCLE, SMOOTH) or the NERVOUS SYSTEM.
As parent above, with diarrhea
As parent above, without diarrhea
A group of bowel disorders which are characterised by chronic abdominal complaints without a structural or biochemical cause that could explain symptoms

Infrequent or difficult evacuation of FECES. These symptoms are associated with a variety of causes, including low DIETARY FIBER intake, emotional or nervous disturbances, systemic and structural disorders, drug-induced aggravation, and infections.
Frequent or urgent passage of loose or watery stool with no identifiable cause
A group of bowel disorders which are characterised by chronic abdominal complaints without a structural or biochemical cause that could explain symptoms [NOS]

An infected cavity filled with pus found near the anus or rectum resulting from an acute infection of a small gland just inside the anus, when bacteria or foreign matter enters the tissue through the gland. Certain conditions - colitis or other inflammation of the intestine, for example - can sometimes make these infections more likely.  The abscess is usually associated with symptoms of pain and swelling around the anus. Individuals may also experience fatigue, fevers and chills.

Swollen veins in the lower part of the RECTUM or ANUS. Hemorrhoids can be inside the anus (internal), under the skin around the anus (external), or protruding from inside to outside of the anus. People with hemorrhoids may or may not exhibit symptoms which include bleeding, itching, and pain.
As parent above, external without complications

INFLAMMATION of the LIVER with ongoing hepatocellular injury for 6 months or more, characterized by NECROSIS of HEPATOCYTES and inflammatory cell (LEUKOCYTES) infiltration. Chronic hepatitis can be caused by viruses, medications, autoimmune diseases, and other unknown factors.

Liver disease in which the normal microcirculation, the gross vascular anatomy, and the hepatic architecture have been variably destroyed and altered with fibrous septa surrounding regenerated or regenerating parenchymal nodules
Any other definite pathologic process with a characteristic set of signs and symptoms effecting the gallbladder
Abnormal accumulation of serous fluid in the gallbladder
Rapid onset inflammation of the pancreas which does not present with computed tomographic or endoscopic retrograde cholaniopancreatic findings of chronic pancreatitis.
Persistent or recurrent inflammation of the pancreas which may present with specific computed tomographic or endoscopic retrograde cholaniopancreatic findings.
Any other definite pathologic process with a characteristic set of signs and symptoms effecting the pancreas
Defective transport of nutrients or water through the intestinal mucous membrane due to infectious, autoimmune, enzymatic and dysproteinemic lesions or other causes.
Defective transport of nutrients or water through the intestinal mucous membrane due to unspecified etiology
Vomiting of blood that is either fresh bright red, or older "coffee-ground" in character. It generally indicates bleeding of theupper gastrointestinal track.

An abscess is a localized collection of pus in any part of the body that is surrounded by swelling (inflammation).#A furuncle (boil) is a skin infection involving an entire hair follicle and nearby skin tissue.#A carbuncle is a skin infection that often involves a group of hair follicles. The infected material forms a lump, called mass, which occurs deep in the skin.

Abscess of the face: a localized collection of pus in the skin of the face that is surrounded by swelling (inflammation).#Furuncle (boil) of the face: an infection in the skin of the face involving an entire hair follicle and nearby skin tissue.#Carbuncle of the face: a skin infection that often involves a group of hair follicles on the face. The infected material forms a lump, called mass, which occurs deep in the skin.

Abscess of the neck: a localized collection of pus in the skin of the neck that is surrounded by swelling (inflammation).#Furuncle (boil) of the neck: an infection in the skin of the neck involving an entire hair follicle and nearby skin tissue.#Carbuncle of the neck: a skin infection that often involves a group of hair follicles on the neck. The infected material forms a lump, called mass, which occurs deep in the skin.

Abscess of the trunk: a localized collection of pus in the skin of the trunk that is surrounded by swelling (inflammation).#Furuncle (boil) of the trunk: an infection in the skin of the trunk involving an entire hair follicle and nearby skin tissue.#Carbuncle of the trunk: a skin infection that often involves a group of hair follicles on the trunk. The infected material forms a lump, called mass, which occurs deep in the skin.

Abscess of the buttock: a localized collection of pus in the skin of the buttock that is surrounded by swelling (inflammation).#Furuncle (boil) of the buttock: an infection in the skin of the buttock involving an entire hair follicle and nearby skin tissue.#Carbuncle of the buttock: a skin infection that often involves a group of hair follicles on the buttock. The infected material forms a lump, called mass, which occurs deep in the skin.

Abscess of the limb: a localized collection of pus in the skin of the limb that is surrounded by swelling (inflammation).#Furuncle (boil) of the limb: an infection in the skin of the limb involving an entire hair follicle and nearby skin tissue.#Carbuncle of the limb: a skin infection that often involves a group of hair follicles on the limb. The infected material forms a lump, called mass, which occurs deep in the skin.

Abscess: a localized collection of pus in the skin of another site that is surrounded by swelling (inflammation).#Furuncle (boil): an infection in the skin of another site involving an entire hair follicle and nearby skin tissue.#Carbuncle: a skin infection that often involves a group of hair follicles on another site. The infected material forms a lump, called mass, which occurs deep in the skin.

Abscess: a localized collection of pus in the skin of an unspecified site that is surrounded by swelling (inflammation).#Furuncle (boil): an infection in the skin of an unspecified site involving an entire hair follicle and nearby skin tissue.#Carbuncle: a skin infection that often involves a group of hair follicles on an unspecified site. The infected material forms a lump, called mass, which occurs deep in the skin.

An acute, diffuse, and suppurative inflammation of loose connective tissue, particularly the deep subcutaneous tissues, and sometimes muscle, which is most commonly seen as a result of infection of a wound, ulcer, or other skin lesions.

An acute, diffuse, and suppurative inflammation of loose connective tissue, particularly the deep subcutaneous tissues, and sometimes muscle of the finger and toe, which is most commonly seen as a result of infection of a wound, ulcer, or other skin lesions.

An acute, diffuse, and suppurative inflammation of loose connective tissue, particularly the deep subcutaneous tissues, and sometimes muscle of other sites, which is most commonly seen as a result of infection of a wound, ulcer, or other skin lesions.
Rapid onset inflammation of the lymph nodes of the trunk
Any purulent skin disease involving either free skin or the adnexal structures.

Any other condition which includes the development of blisters, the accumulation of fluid between cells in the upper layers of the skin, specifically the epidermis (top layers) or dermis (layer between the epidermis). The type of disease depends upon what level in the skin the blisters form and where they are located on the body.

Any unspecified condition which includes the development of blisters, the accumulation of fluid between cells in the upper layers of the skin, specifically the epidermis (top layers) or dermis (layer between the epidermis).

A chronic inflammatory genetically determined disease of the skin marked by increased ability to form reagin (IgE), with increased susceptibility to allergic rhinitis and asthma, and hereditary disposition to a lowered threshold for pruritus. It is manifested by lichenification, excoriation, and crusting, mainly on the flexural surfaces of the elbow and knee.

Any other chronic inflammatory genetically determined disease of the skin marked by increased ability to form reagin (IgE), with increased susceptibility to allergic rhinitis and asthma, and hereditary disposition to a lowered threshold for pruritus. It is manifested by lichenification, excoriation, and crusting, mainly on the flexural surfaces of the elbow and knee.

A chronic inflammatory disease of the skin with unknown etiology. It is characterized by moderate erythema, dry, moist, or greasy  scaling and yellow crusted patches on various areas, especially the scalp, that exfoliate as dandruff. Seborrheic dermatitis is common in children and adolescents with HIV infection.

A type of acute or chronic skin reaction in which sensitivity is manifested by reactivity to allergic sensitization to various substances coming in contact with the skin. These substances subsequently produce inflammatory reactions in the skin of those who have acquired hypersensitivity to them as a result of prior exposure.
A type of acute or chronic skin reaction in which sensitivity is manifested by reactivity to irritating materials or substances coming in contact with the skin
A type of acute or chronic skin reaction in which sensitivity is manifested by reactivity to other irritating materials or substances coming in contact with the skin

A type of acute or chronic skin reaction in which sensitivity is manifested by reactivity to various plant substances coming in contact with the skin. These substances subsequently produce inflammatory reactions in the skin of those who have acquired hypersensitivity to them as a result of prior exposure.
Any inflammation of the skin which causes scaling and / or exfoliation of the skin
An intense itching sensation that produces the urge to rub or scratch the skin to obtain relief.
An intense itching sensation that produces the urge to rub or scratch the skin of the scrotum to obtain relief.
Any other inflammation of the skin
Any inflammation of the skin which is transmittable to others

A common genetically determined, chronic, inflammatory skin disease characterized by rounded erythematous, dry, scaling patches. The lesions have a predilection for nails, scalp, genitalia, extensor surfaces, and the lumbosacral region. Accelerated epidermopoiesis is considered to be the fundamental pathologic feature in psoriasis.
A rare skin eruption that is characterized by acute, extensive formation of sterile pustules on the skin of the palms of the hands and soles of the feet, fever, and peripheral blood leukocytosis.

An inflammatory, pruritic disease of the skin and mucous membranes, which can be either generalized or localized. It is characterized by distinctive purplish, flat-topped papules having a predilection for the trunk and flexor surfaces. The lesions may be discrete or coalesce to form plaques. Histologically, there is a "saw-tooth" pattern of epidermal hyperplasia and vacuolar alteration of the basal layer of the epidermis along with an intense upper dermal inflammatory infiltrate composed predominantly of T-cells. Etiology is unknown.

A skin and mucous membrane disease characterized by an eruption of macules, papules, nodules, vesicles, and/or bullae with characteristic "bull's-eye" lesions usually occurring on the dorsal aspect of the hands and forearms.

An erythematous eruption commonly associated with drug reactions or infection and characterized by inflammatory nodules that are usually tender, multiple, and bilateral. These nodules are located predominantly on the shins with less common occurrence on the thighs and forearms. They undergo characteristic color changes ending in temporary bruise-like areas. This condition usually subsides in 3-6 weeks without scarring or atrophy.
An injury to the skin causing erythema, tenderness, and sometimes blistering and resulting from excessive exposure to the sun. The reaction is produced by the ultraviolet radiation in sunlight.
A vascular reaction of the skin characterized by erythema and wheal formation due to localized increase of vascular permeability as a result of exposure to the sun.
A microscopically inflammatory, usually reversible, patchy hair loss occurring in sharply defined areas and usually involving the beard or scalp
Localized skin inflammation as a result of overactivity of the oil glands at the base of hair follicles.
Disorder of eccrine sweat, also called miliaria, is due to the occlusion of the eccrine glands, with the subsequent retention of sweat within the skin.

A syndrome of cutaneous changes associated with sweat retention and extravasation of sweat at different levels in the skin resulting from apocrine duct obstruction. The sweat then seeps into the epidermis, producing pruritic erythematous papulovesicles. Also known as prickly heat.

Abnormally diminished or absent perspiration. Both generalized and segmented (reduced or absent sweating in circumscribed locations) forms of the disease are usually associated with other underlying conditions.
A rare condition characterized by the secretion of colored sweat. It is caused by the deposition of lipofuscin in the sweat glands.

A disorder consisting of areas of macular depigmentation, commonly on extensor aspects of extremities, on the face or neck, and in skin folds. Age of onset is often in young adulthood and the condition tends to progress gradually with lesions enlarging and extending until a quiescent state is reached.
Disorders of increased melanin pigmentation that develop without preceding inflammatory disease that result in patchy brown or dark brown skin discoloration.
Benign adnexal neoplasms that present as multiple oval, brown-to-black plaques, located mostly on the chest and back. The age of onset is usually in the fourth or fifth decade.

A circumscribed melanosis consisting of a brown-pigmented, velvety verrucosity or fine papillomatosis appearing in the axillae and other body folds. It occurs in association with endocrine disorders, underlying malignancy, administration of certain drugs, or as in inherited disorder.
Localized hyperplasia of the horny layer of the epidermis due to pressure or friction.

An idiopathic, rapidly evolving, and severely debilitating disease occurring most commonly in association with chronic ulcerative colitis. It is characterized by the presence of boggy, purplish ulcers with undermined borders, appearing mostly on the legs. The majority of cases are in people between 40 and 60 years old. Its etiology is unknown.

A sharply elevated, irregularly shaped, progressively enlarging scar resulting from formation of excessive amounts of collagen in the dermis during connective tissue repair. It is differentiated from a hypertrophic scar in that the former does not spread to surrounding tissues.
A lesion on the surface of the skin of the lower limb produced by the sloughing of inflammatory necrotic tissue which is not coded elsewhere.

A disorder of the skin, the oral mucosa, and the gingiva, that usually presents as a solitary polypoid capillary hemangioma often resulting from trauma. It is manifested as an inflammatory response with similar characteristics to those of a granuloma.

Inflammation of a joint or joints due to a bacterial infection, typically secondary to haematological spread, which is characterized by joint pain, swelling, pseudoparalysis, fever, and reduced or absent range of motion

Primary osteoarthritis occuring in an otherwise intact knee joint, involving genetically related, age-related or use-related degeneration with microscopic and macroscopic anatomical changes, which ultimately limit motion in one or more joints. Changes to the joint include increasing cartilage loss and osseous transformation such as sclerosis, osteophyte formation and cysts as well as potential inflammatory changes in surrounding soft tissue structures.
Noninflammatory degenerative disease of one or both of the first carpometacarpal joints
Noninflammatory degenerative disease of a joint or joints
Inflammatory joint disease affecting the axial skeleton, not detailed in code series (M45)

Changes in the structure of the spine causing damage to vertebrae and surrounding tissue secondary to infection, injury, tumors, infections, bone changes that come with age etc. Spinal diseases often limit movement and cause pain when bone changes put pressure on the spinal cord or nerves.

A series of clinical syndromes characterized by traumatic and/or degenerative insult to cervical discs resulting in reduced disc height, stenosis, herniation and/or sequestration, etc resulting in neck and/or arm pain, weakness and/or paresthesias

A series of clinical syndromes which specifically affect the lumbar spine, lumbar discs, intervertebral foramina and/or spinal nerve roots, resulting in nerve root compromise, low back and/or leg pain, weakness and/or paresthesias.
Inflammation of skeletal muscle secondary to infection and/or autoimmune reaction
An immune cell complex formed to sequester inert foreign materials that are too large to be ingested by phages
The pathological separation or tearing of muscle fibers from other muscle fibers, tendons or fascia
A loss of muscle tissue and/or tone secondary to disuse or neurogenic compromise
A stretched or torn muscle usually secondary to traumatic pulling or twisting
Inflammation of the synovial membrane or lining of the sheath surrounding the tendon, respectively, which is characterized by pain, particularly with motion and intermittent swelling due to effusion.

aka cumulative trauma disorders, a vast array of diagnoses relating to occupational, recreational or habitual activity-related tissue damage that results from repetitive demand over the course of time
A condition characterized by inflammation of the bursa that overlies the olecranon process at the proximal aspect of the ulna
A condition characterized by inflammation of bursae of the elbow not detailed in code (M70.2)
aka "frozen shoulder," an idiopathic condition characterized by the progressive loss of active and passive ranges of motion in a capsular pattern secondary to pain and contracture
Inflammation of tissues around the joints of the wrist
Bone fracture secondary to a systemic decrease in bone mass, micro-architectural deterioration of bone tissue and concomitant increase in bone fragility.
Susceptibility to bone fracture secondary to a systemic decrease in bone mass and micro-architectural deterioration of bone tissue with concomitant increase in bone fragility.
Susceptibility to bone fracture secondary to a systemic decrease in bone mass and micro-architectural deterioration of bone tissue related to hormonal changes associated with menopause
A disease characterized by defects in bone mineralization and bone softening secondary to vitamin D deficiency.

A disorder characterized by pathologically excessive resorption of bone by multinucleated osteoclasts and abnormal modeling of disorganized, woven bone by osteoblasts with resultant bone vascularization, weakness, enlargement and deformity.

A group of disorders that cause swelling or inflammation of the internal kidney structures (specifically, the glomeruli); acute nephritic syndrome is often caused by an immune response that is triggered by an infection or other disease

aka "rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis", a disease of the kidney characterized clinically by a rapid decrease in the glomerular filtration rate (GFR) of at least 50% over a short period, from a few days to 3 months; the main pathologic finding is extensive glomerular crescent formation.

The presence of red blood cells (RBCs) in the urine. In microscopic hematuria, the urine appears normal to the naked eye, but examination with a microscope shows a high number of RBCs. Gross hematuria can be seen with the naked eyeÂ—the urine is red or the color of cola.  Usually the blood goes away within 24 hours; if it persists, or frequently comes back, it is regarded as recurrent or persistent.

A long-standing renal syndrome characterized by the presence of glomerular pores which allow proteins and red blood cells to pass into the urine (vs nephrotic syndrome which only allows protein into the urine)

A condition characterized by severe PROTEINURIA, greater than 3.5 g/day in an average adult. The substantial loss of protein in the urine results in complications such as HYPOPROTEINEMIA; generalized EDEMA; HYPERTENSION; and HYPERLIPIDEMIAS. Diseases associated with nephrotic syndrome generally cause chronic kidney dysfunction.

A renal syndrome characterized by the presence of glomerular pores which allow proteins and red blood cells to pass into the urine (vs nephrotic syndrome which only allows protein into the urine) [NOS]

A group of inherited conditions characterized initially by HEMATURIA and slowly progressing to RENAL INSUFFICIENCY. The most common form is the Alport syndrome (hereditary nephritis with HEARING LOSS) which is caused by mutations in genes for TYPE IV COLLAGEN and defective GLOMERULAR BASEMENT MEMBRANE
Diseases classified elsewhere characterized by glomerulonephritis and glomerulosclerosis and ultimately, renal failure.
Infectious and parasitic diseases classified elsewhere resulting in glomerulonephritis, glomerulosclerosis and ultimately, renal failure.
A disease characterized by inflammation of and generally reversible damage to tubules and/or the interstitium of the kidney, renal tubular dysfunction with or without renal failure.

A disease characterized by inflammation of and damage to tubules and/or the interstitium of the kidney, interstitial scarring, fibrosis and tubule atrophy resulting in progressive chronic renal insufficiency

A disease characterized by inflammation of and damage to tubules and/or the interstitium of the kidney while sparing the glomeruli  secondary to immune reaction or toxic agent [chronicity not specified]
A condition characterized by a blockage in the flow of urine causing it to back up, injuring one or both kidneys.
A collection of purulent material in and/or around the kidneys, with a presentation that is insidious (> 14d), secondary to ascending bacterial infection
Stones in the KIDNEY and/or URETER, usually formed in the urine-collecting area of the kidney (KIDNEY PELVIS). Their sizes vary and most contains CALCIUM OXALATE.

Low-density crystals or stones in the lower part of the URINARY TRACT, including the bladder. Their chemical compositions often include CALCIUM OXALATE, magnesium ammonium phosphate (struvite), CYSTINE, or URIC ACID
Low-density crystals or stones in any part of the URINARY TRACT secondary to other diseases classified elsewhere
Disorders not detailed in codes N25.0-N25.1 such as lightwood-albright syndrome, renal tubular acidosis NOS and secondary hyperparathyroidism resulting from impaired renal tubular function
Unspecified disorders resulting from impaired renal tubular function
Unspecified disorders of the kidney and ureter
Infectious and parasitic diseases classified elsewhere resulting in disoders of the kidney and/or ureter not detailed in codes N25-N28
Sudden or severe inflammation of the bladder or lower urinary tract secondary to E. coli infection

A condition with recurring discomfort or pain in the URINARY BLADDER and the surrounding pelvic region without an identifiable disease. Severity of pain in interstitial cystitis varies greatly and often is accompanied by increased urination frequency and urgency.
Other bladder disorders not detailed in codes N30-N31
Bladder disorders secondary to diseases classified elsewhere (other than N33.0 tuberculosis cystitis)
Inflammation involving the URETHRA. Similar to CYSTITIS, clinical symptoms range from vague discomfort to painful urination (DYSURIA), urethral discharge, or both.
Inflammation involving the URETHRA. Similar to CYSTITIS, clinical symptoms range from vague discomfort to painful urination (DYSURIA), urethral discharge, or both.
Disorders of the urethra not detailed in codes N34-N36
The presence of proteins in the urine, an indicator of KIDNEY DISEASES.

Accumulation of serous fluid between the layers of membrane (tunica vaginalis) covering the TESTIS in the SCROTUM and/or a cystic dilation of the EPIDIDYMIS, usually in the head portion (caput epididymis); the cyst fluid contains dead SPERMATOZOA and can be easily differentiated from TESTICULAR HYDROCELE and other testicular lesions.

Inflammation of a TESTIS. It has many features of EPIDIDYMITIS, such as swollen SCROTUM; PAIN; PYURIA; and FEVER. It is usually related to infections in the URINARY TRACT, which likely spread to the EPIDIDYMIS and then the TESTIS through either the VAS DEFERENS or the lymphatics of the SPERMATIC CORD and/or Inflammation of the EPIDIDYMIS. Its clinical features include enlarged epididymis, a swollen SCROTUM; PAIN; PYURIA; and FEVER. It is usually related to infections in the URINARY TRACT, which likely spread to the EPIDIDYMIS through either the VAS DEFERENS or the lymphatics of the SPERMATIC CORD.
Other disorders of the penis not detailed in code N47
A disorder characterized by inflammation of the foreskin and glans in uncircumcised males
Typically characterized by superficial inflammation of the scrotal skin associated with poor hygiene and chafing
A deep furrow of the nipple and/or abnormal passage or communication yielding incontinence
A condition (of the breast) in which the death of adipose tissue results in neutral fats being split into fatty acids and glycerol.

Inflammation of the fallopian tube, characterized by a typical inflammatory response (redness and oedema).  It is usually manifested by lower abdominal pain and tenderness, fever, increased pulse rate, hypermenorrhoea and/or metrorrhagia.  The disorder may resolve or result in fibrosis, hydrosalpinx, pyosalpinx, or cyst formation.

A spectrum of inflammation involving the UTERUS and the supporting tissues. It is usually caused by an ascending infection of organisms from the endocervix.  Such inflammation can lead to functional impairment and infertility.
Inflammation of the UTERINE CERVIX.
A spectrum of inflammation involving the female upper genital tract and the supporting tissues in conditions not defined in codes N70-N72

Abnormal descent of a pelvic organ resulting in the protrusion of the organ beyond its normal anatomical confines. Symptoms often include vaginal discomfort, DYSPAREUNIA; URINARY STRESS INCONTINENCE; and FECAL INCONTINENCE.
Abnormal communication between two internal reproductive organs or between an internal organ and the surface of the body.

Discrete abnormal tissue masses that protrude into the lumen of the corpus uteri. Polyps can be spheroidal, hemispheroidal, or irregular mound-shaped structures attached to the MUCOUS MEMBRANE of the lumen wall either by a stalk, pedunculus, or by a broad base.
Retroversion and/or incarceration of the uterus secondary to the intermittent myometrial contractions of pregnancy
Narrowing, imperforation or occlusion of the vaginal opening
Enlargement of the female external genitalia, i.e. clitoris, labia, vestibule and/or glands
Idiopathic abnormally infrequent menstruation
aka "menorrhagia", excessive uterine bleeding during MENSTRUATION
Vaginal bleeding after sexual contact
Periods characterized by physiological changes associated with the transition period between fertility to infertility, including the permanent cessation of a menstruation.
Diminished or absent ability of a female to achieve conception due to anovulation
Diminished or absent ability of a female to achieve conception of tubal etiology
Iatrogenic genitourinary disorder [NOS]

A condition in which the embryo implants outside the cavity of the uterus. Most ectopic pregnancies (>96%) occur in the fallopian tubes (tubal pregnancy). I can also occur in other locations, such as uterine cervix; ovary; or abdominal cavity.
A hydatidiform mole is a rare mass or growth that forms inside the uterus at the beginning of a pregnancy. It is a type of gestational trophoblastic disease (GTD).
The retention in the uterus of a dead fetus two months or more after its death.
Expulsion of the product of fertilization (or fetus)  before completing the term of gestation and without deliberate interference.  Also known as a miscarriage.
Persistently high systemic arterial blood pressure (exceeding 140/90 mmHg) causing complications during pregnancy, labor, and the period which follows giving birth.
Persistently high systemic arterial blood pressure (exceeding 140/90 mmHg) caused by pregnancy, without presence of significant amounts of protein in the urine.
Persistently high systemic arterial blood pressure (exceeding 140/90 mmHg) during a the period of pregnancy.
Intractable vomiting that develops in early pregnancy and persists which can lead to dehydration and weight loss.
A heterogeneous group of disorders characterized by hyperglycemia and glucose intolerance during the period of pregnancy
An imbalanced nutritional status resulted from insufficient intake of nutrients to meet normal physiological requirement during the period of pregnancy.
Any condition related to the state or period of pregnancy.
Any other complication related to the state or period of pregnancy with multiple fetuses.
Care provided for the pregnant female for incorrect position or orientation of the fetus at near term or during labor, determined by its relation to the spine of the mother and the birth canal.
Care provided for the pregnant female necessary due to malformation of the pregnant female's uterus present at or before the time of birth.
Care provided for the pregnant female necessary due to the presence of a uterine tumor at the time of pregnancy.
Care provided for the pregnant female for any other abnormality associated with the pregnant uterus.
Care provided for the pregnant female necessary due to some abnormality of the vagina.
Care provided for the pregnant female due to suspected or actual damage to the fetus by some drug.
Care provided for the pregnant female due to suspected or actual damage to the fetus by some other medical procedure.

Care provided for the pregnant female following rhesus isoimmunization, the process by which fetal Rh+ erythrocytes enter the circulation of an Rh- mother, causing her to produce immuniglobulin G antibodies, which can cross the placenta and destroy the erythrocytes of Rh+ fetuses.
Premature separation of the normally implanted placenta from the uterus with associated hemorrhage due to abnormalities in blood coagulation
Childbirth before 37 weeks of pregnancy (259 days from the first day of the mother's last menstrual period, or 245 days after fertilization).
Contractions of the uterine muscle which are excessively long, strong or unequal.
Irregular tearing of the body region lying between the vulva and the anus during delivery of the fetus.
Any other wound or injury inflicted on the body of the pregnant female as a result of pregnancy, labor, or the puerperium, or conditions associated with these.
Forcible or traumatic tear or break of the uterus (the hollow thick-walled muscular organ in the female pelvis) prior to the onset of the repetitive uterine contractions associated with childbirth.
Any other wound or injury inflicted to the pelvic organs of the pregnant female as a result of pregnancy, labor, or the puerperium, or conditions associated with these.
A collection of blood outside the blood vessels within the pelvis during pregnancy, labor, or the puerperium.
An abnormal elevation of body temperature during the period of repetitive uterine contractions associated with childbirth.
Inflammatory responses of the epithelium of the urinary tract to microbial invasions following childbirth. They are often bacterial infections with associated bacteruria and pyuria.
Any other specified infection occurring in puerperium, the period of 6-8 weeks after giving birth.

A group of diseases in which the dominant feature is the involvement of the cardiac muscle itself occurring in puerperium, the period of 6-8 weeks after giving birth.. Cardiomyopathies are classified according to their predominant pathophysiological features or their etiological/pathological factors.
Any complication occurring in puerperium, the period of 6-8 weeks after giving birth, which is not otherwise specified.

Cracks of the skin in the areola of the breast associated with childbirth and breast feeding. The causes of a cracked nipple include delicate nipple skin of the mother and forceful sucking and chewing of the baby because of a flat, sinking or a small nipple, or due to insufficient lactation.
Failure of the secretion of milk from any cause other than the normal ending of the lactation period.

Excessive or inappropriate lactation in females or males, and not necessarily related to pregnancy. Galactorrhea can occur either unilaterally or bilaterally, and be profuse or sparse. Its most common cause is hyperprolactinemia.

The death of a woman while pregnant or within 42 days of termination of pregnancy, irrespective of the duration and the site of the pregnancy, from unspecific cause related to or aggravated by pregnancy or its management.
Complications during pregnancy, delivery, or the period of 6-8 weeks after delivery due to any of the infectious diseases of man and other animals caused by species of mycobacterium.
Complications during pregnancy, delivery, or the period of 6-8 weeks after delivery due to any condition coded elsewhere

Yellow discoloration of the skin, mucus membranes and sclera in a newborn due to unspecified causes. It is a sign of neonatal hyperbilirubinemia. Most cases are transient self-limiting, occurring in the first week of life, but some can be a sign of pathological disorders, particularly liver diseases.
Any other impairment, arrest, or reversal of the normal flow of intestinal toward the anal canal in a newborn
A lack of interest in feeding or a problem receiving the proper amount of nutrition in a newborn.

A severe irreversible decline in the ability of kidneys to remove wastes, concentrate urine, and maintain electrolyte balance; blood pressure; and calcium metabolism which existed at, or often before, birth.

A malformation of the nervous system caused by the failure of neuropores to close. Infants are born with intact spinal cords, cerebellums, and brainstems, but lack formation of neural structures above this level. The skull is only partially formed but the eyes are usually normal.
Partial or complete opacity on or in the lens or capsule of one or both eyes, impairing vision or causing blindness; typically diagnosed at birth
Also called nasal agenesis, it is a very rare anomaly in which external nose does not develop and the nasal capity is totally or partially obliterated.
Congenital anomalies of nose are the product of errors in embryogenesis (malformations) on nose or the result of intrauterine events that affect embryonic and fetal growth

Congenital fissure of the soft and/or hard palate, due to faulty fusion WITH congenital defect in the upper lip where the maxillary prominence fails to merge with the merged medial nasal prominences. It is thought to be caused by faulty migration of the mesoderm in the head region.
A series of conditions resulting in reduced kidney function including a congenital absence of both kidneys
A condition characterized by the congenital underdevelopment of a kidney
The embryological, incomplete fusion of renal lobules and/or kidneys
A birth defect characterized by an abnormally positioned kidney; may be asymptomatic or result in urine blockage, infection or kidney stones
A series of congenital developmental aberrations including renal agenesis, renal dysplasia, renal aplasia and/or multicystic dysplastic kidney.
Bleeding from the nose
Expectoration or spitting of blood originating from any part of the respiratory tract, usually from hemorrhage in the lung parenchyma and the bronchial arteries.
A clinical syndrome with acute abdominal pain that is severe, localized, and rapid onset. Acute abdomen may be caused by a variety of disorders, injuries, or diseases
Production or presence of gas in the gastrointestinal tract which may be expelled through the anus and other conditions associated with the production or presence of gas in the GI tract.
Failure of voluntary control of the anal sphincters, with involuntary passage of feces and flatus.
A clinical manifestation of hyperbilirubinemia of unspecified origin, characterized by the yellowish staining of the skin; mucus membranes and sclera.
Accumulation or retention of free fluid between the tissues lining the abdomen and abdominal organs (the peritoneal cavity).
A collection of gait abnormalities due to affected motor control, sensory feedback, and muscle strength.
The presence of red blood cells (RBCs) in the urine due to unspecified etiology
Decrease or loss of bladder control.
An imprecise term which may refer to a sense of spatial disorientation, motion of the environment, or lightheadedness.

A cognitive disorder marked by an impaired ability to comprehend or express language in its written or spoken form. This condition is caused by diseases which affect the language areas of the dominant hemisphere. Clinical features are used to classify the various subtypes of this condition. General categories include receptive, expressive, and mixed forms of aphasia.
Difficulty and/or pain in phonation or speaking.
An abnormal elevation of body temperature of unknown origin, often as a result of a pathologic process.

Malais is a loss of physical and mental stamina, rapid muscular and cognitive fatigability, post-exertional fatigue, malaise and/or pain, and a tendency for other symptoms to worsen. Fatigue is the state of weariness following a period of exertion, mental or physical, characterized by a decreased capacity for work and reduced efficiency to respond to stimuli.

Clinical or subclinical disturbances of cortical function due to a sudden, abnormal, excessive, and disorganized discharge of brain cells. Clinical manifestations include abnormal motor, sensory and psychic phenomena.
Bleeding or escape of blood from a vessel.
Abnormal fluid accumulation in tissues or body cavities not coded elsewhere.
Excessive sweating which may be induced by a hot, humid environment, by fever, or by vigorous exercise.
Excessive sweating in sites such as the palms, soles, axillae, inguinal folds, and the perineal area.
Excessive sweating of unspecified origin.

Greater than normal levels of glucose found in laboratory examination of the blood to check how the body breaks down (metabolizes) blood sugar. Positive findings may indicate diabetes or Cushing diseases, among other things.
Any other result in laboratory examination of the urine which is beyond normal limits for that finding.

The presence of free hemoglobin in the urine, indicating hemolysis of erythrocytes within the vascular system. After saturating the hemoglobin-binding proteins (haptoglobins), free hemoglobin begins to appear in the urine.
Damage inflicted on the surface or shallow tissues of the head as the direct or indirect result of an external force, with or without disruption of structural continuity.
Damage inflicted on the surface or shallow tissues of the ear as the direct or indirect result of an external force, with or without disruption of structural continuity.
Broken bones of the cranial vault
Fractures which extend through the base of the skull, usually involving the petrous bone.
Fracture of the largest and strongest bone of the face constituting the lower jaw.
Displacement of the mandible, the largest and strongest bone of the face constituting the lower jaw.

A collective term for muscle and ligament injuries of the tissues associated with the mandible without dislocation or fracture; a joint injury in which some of the fibers of a supporting ligament are ruptured but the continuity of the ligament remains intact. A strain is an overstretching or overexertion of some part of the musculature.
Injuries to the eyeball and surrounding tissue resulting in hemorrhage, usually manifested in the skin.
Forcible or traumatic tearing or breaking of the eyeball with protrusion or loss of the tissues and fluids located within the eyeball.
Damage inflicted on the eyeball and surrounding tissues as the direct or indirect result of an external force, with or without disruption of structural continuity.

Damage inflicted on the eyeball and surrounding tissues as the direct or indirect result of an external force, with or without disruption of structural continuity with the specific location unspecified
Damage inflicted on the tissues of the brain as the direct or indirect result of an external force, with or without disruption of structural continuity.
Damage inflicted on the tissues of the head as the direct or indirect result of an crushing external force.
Break of bones in the cervical spine
Displacement of one or more bones of the cervical spine

A collective term for muscle and ligament injuries of the tissues associated with the cervical spine without dislocation or fracture; a joint injury in which some of the fibers of a supporting ligament are ruptured but the continuity of the ligament remains intact. A strain is an overstretching or overexertion of some part of the musculature.
Damage inflicted on the surface or shallow tissues of the thoraxas the direct or indirect result of an external force, with or without disruption of structural continuity.
Breaks of the sternum bone
Break of any one or more of the rib bones
Damage inflicted on the surface or shallow tissues of the abdomen, lower back and pelvis as the direct or indirect result of an external force, with or without disruption of structural continuity.
Broken bone in the lumbar spine or pelvis

A collective term for muscle and ligament injuries of the tissues associated with the lumbar spine without dislocation or fracture; a joint injury in which some of the fibers of a supporting ligament are ruptured but the continuity of the ligament remains intact. A strain is an overstretching or overexertion of some part of the musculature.

A collective term for muscle and ligament injuries of other, unspecified tissues associated with the lumbar spine and pelvis without dislocation or fracture; a joint injury in which some of the fibers of a supporting ligament are ruptured but the continuity of the ligament remains intact. A strain is an overstretching or overexertion of some part of the musculature.
Damage inflicted on the liver or gallbladder as the direct or indirect result of an external force, with or without disruption of structural continuity.
A break in one or both of the clavicles
A break in one or both of the scapulae
A break located within the proximal 50% of the humerus
Displacement of the humerus from the scapula.

A collective term for muscle and ligament injuries of the tissues associated with the shoulder joint without dislocation or fracture; a joint injury in which some of the fibers of a supporting ligament are ruptured but the continuity of the ligament remains intact. A strain is an overstretching or overexertion of some part of the musculature.
A break in one or both of the radius and/or ulna
A collective term for muscle and ligament injuries of the tissues associated with, or displacement of the bones of, the elbow.

A collective term for muscle and ligament injuries of the tissues associated with the elbow without dislocation or fracture; a joint injury in which some of the fibers of a supporting ligament are ruptured but the continuity of the ligament remains intact. A strain is an overstretching or overexertion of some part of the musculature.
A break in one of the bones of the wrist or hand
A break in one or more of the carpal bones of the wrist
A break in the first metacarpal bone, that which is part of the thumb
A break in one or more of the phalanges
Displacement of one or more of the bones of the wrist
Displacement of one or more of the phalanges

A collective term for muscle and ligament injuries of the tissues associated with the wrist without dislocation or fracture; a joint injury in which some of the fibers of a supporting ligament are ruptured but the continuity of the ligament remains intact. A strain is an overstretching or overexertion of some part of the musculature.
A break in the femur, longest and largest bone of the skeleton, situated between the hip and the knee
A collective term for muscle and ligament injuries of the tissues associated with, or displacement of the bones of, the hip.

A collective term for muscle and ligament injuries of the tissues associated with the hip without dislocation or fracture; a joint injury in which some of the fibers of a supporting ligament are ruptured but the continuity of the ligament remains intact. A strain is an overstretching or overexertion of some part of the musculature.
A break in the patellar bone (kneecap)
A break located within the proximal 50% of the tibia
A fracture of the medial malleolus, the bony landmark located on the distal end of the tibia
Displacement of the patella from the femoral groove.

A collective term for muscle and ligament injuries of other and unspecified tissues associated with the knee without dislocation or fracture; a joint injury in which some of the fibers of a supporting ligament are ruptured but the continuity of the ligament remains intact. A strain is an overstretching or overexertion of some part of the musculature.
A break in one or more of the phalanges or metatarsals of the foot.
A break in one or more of the tarsal bones of the ankle
A break in one or more of the metatarsal bones of the foot
Displacement of one or more bones of the ankle, including the tarsals
Displacement of one or more of the phalanges of the foot
Damage inflicted on the muscular or tendinous tissues of the ankle or foot as the direct or indirect result of an external force, with or without disruption of structural continuity.
The condition refers to the fracture of lower limbs in which the position is not specified.
The condition refers to the fracture of lower limbs in which the position is not specified.
Damage inflicted on the body in an unspecified area as the direct or indirect result of an external force, with or without disruption of structural continuity.
Objects that inadvertently enter the ear from the environment.
Objects that inadvertently enter the pharynx from the environment.
Injury to the tissues of the head and neck caused by contact with, for example, heat, steam, chemicals, or electricity.
Damage to surface tissues as the result of low environmental temperatures.
Damage to surface tissues of the head as the result of low environmental temperatures.
A condition or physical state produced by the ingestion, injection or inhalation of, or exposure to antibiotics which may target / effect the entire body.
Any other complication associated with the administration of anaesthesia
This term refers to injury from dog bite or attack, including physical damage and infection.
This term refers to injury from reptile bite or attack, including physical damage and infection.
